content.description: The crux is at the end of the route. The ledge at the end is off!!! High feet!!!! It is a great photo-op. It was named this because Kevin broke a hold and fell 15 feet onto jagged rocks. Kevin was not injured, but definitely use a crash pad here. It has mostly solid rock, but watch your step and grip.
content.location: This is on the left side of the beach on a very large block that is about 15 or 20 feet high. The start is on these massive jugs that are great, and then traverse to the end which is no feet on the lip, mostly at the end but throughout the entire climb. Top out and then downclimb the side.

content.description: The crux is at the very beginning, if there is any crux. There are many great jugs and some easy slopers.  It was named so because Kevin got on this route, broke a hold and fell, slightly scraping up his arm in the process. The first ascent was an onsight and the first route at the crag.
content.location: The route is left of the Devil's Block and of the diagonal crack. It is on the end and just goes straight up. The start is on either side of that flake, both sidepulls but amazing jugs. At the end, either jump or downclimb the backside. Top out the finish.

content.description: The crux is going around the corner of the route. The route may be crumbly as it was not well developed. It is worth doing, but it is not the best route at the crag.
content.location:
The route is far left of the main part of the crag. It is a very definitive block and I believe the only climbable boulder left of the rest of the crag. 

  The route is a traverse, and the start is just high hands high feet. You get down by climbing and or jumping. It may or may not be sorta in somebody's property, so just do not make disturbances. There are anchors near the block that look like glue ins, but don't be fooled, they are probably from boats and such.

content.protection:
Skill or a pad. 

  To be edited in.

content.description: The beach can become crowded during summer months. The boulders themselves are secluded and bordering some private property. The rock can crumble. Watch out for the Devil's Block (an overhanging block that if climbed on could fall) marked by chalk Xs.
